text: [Music]
Well, I think in our specific case,
what's uh you know has has become I
think a pretty good not happy ending but
at least a good story so far is uh our
crisis at Cadillac was you know we were
literally um dying in in several ways.
one is we had a very old customer base
that is loyal and had always bought
Cadillacs but pretty much 100% American
and and pretty much old and that was in
the uh in the 80s that we were were
continuing to lose sales lose market
share and we had a serious crisis that
uh arguably the flagship division of
General Motors was uh not no longer
going to be competitive and no longer be
the flagship and that isn't a good
situation for GM to be in obviously
having its uh we call bookend division,
but the what should be setting the pace
and what had for the first 60 or 70
years at General Motors um really had a
opportunity for people to move up and to
sort of land and be the ultimate
achievement and success uh symbol at
Cadillac. So we had a serious crisis and
uh we had we spent a considerable amount
of time probably if you added it all up
what upwards of a year around 1998 to uh
kind of go back to square one reevaluate
our total business and I mean total
business all the product and our
positioning our brand what we stood for
our strengths our weaknesses sort of uh
the kinds of things that will be talked
about in management seminars like this
and come to some conclusions with a
brand new strategic plan going forward
as to what we had to do on again all
fronts, product, communication, uh,
marketing to become viable again to
American consumers and not 70 to 80 year
old American consumers, but 35 to
55year-old American consumers that are
in the luxury space that had all gone to
our competitors BMW, Mercedes, Lexus,
and many of the the new luxuries like
Acura and and Audi. So, we had a big
challenge and the price tag for that was
very very large and a and a serious
commitment on General Motors um board
standpoint to come up with that kind of
investment. So, I could go on and in the
the rest of that story, but that was
probably our our biggest uh crisis in my
business having been with Cadillac quite
a while. And uh so we sat down of course
starting in 1998 that uh now is uh is
you know 10 years old but for several
product cycles you know whole new brand
makeover um numerous changes I could go
on for hours about that to try to set us
back on a path and uh make us viable and
and successful again. Uh a large
complicated crisis.
[Music]
